data.text: Long-Distance Relationship during a Long-Distance Bicycle Tour

Advice for those of you who are in a relationship and bike for extended periods of time? How do you make it work? I want to do a two month organized bike trip and my partner isn‚Äôt keen on the idea of me being gone for so long. Them going is not an option.
Tandem?
data.author: Raym Richards

data.text: In fairness to your partner maybe they should be encouraged to elope for two months with their other ‚Äúlove‚Äù‚Ä¶
data.author: Raym Richards

data.text: Interested in the answers. I don't have any good answer, unfortunately. üò≠ Two months would never fly for me, but I have done 1 month. Trying to build the courage to ask for 5 days in 3 weeks.
data.author: Pierre Moreels

data.text: We live in the Midwest. I use our home as a hub. I have ridden off in all directions. When I am gone for over a week, my wife meets me part way through on a rest day.
data.author: Tom Dull

data.text: Maybe try two weeks first. And then every year add a couple weeks.
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: You have to choose what is more important in your life, touring or the relationship. If your partner isn't supportive of what you need to be happy and you give up on your dream to appease them, you'll resent them in the long run. Best to figure these things out now.
data.author: Sean Quinn

data.text: They can either deal with it or not. Pretty simple really. You have two choices, go or don‚Äôt.
data.author: Sue Sommers

data.text: In all reality, if biking is a serious interest and one of the main things that makes you, you, then they should be accepting to what you want/need with tours. The only answer I can give you is COMMUNICATION! All relationships depend on it and so many compromises can be made on both ends with an open mind.
data.author: Liam Terry

data.text: So many people that absolutely suck at relationships are going to say choose the bike or the partner, it can easily be both if you both have an open mind
data.author: Liam Terry

data.text: You don‚Äôt‚Ä¶ DonT ‚Äúmake anything work ‚Äú
data.author: ChRis Kojak

data.text: My bike and I have a wonderful relationship, thank you!
data.author: Carlton Styron

data.text: What Liam said. Talk it out. Does your partner have family/friends nearby as support while you are gone? My wife was not happy with my 8 week trip last summer but found she enjoyed some time alone and spent time with family and friends she probably would not have if I had stayed home. She also goes on her own trips with friends so it works out for us. It‚Äôs a tough one. Talk it out.
data.author: Timothy Dale

data.text: Just send it
data.author: Dylan Jones-Wood

data.text: when I went on my first tour my wife at the time was supportive cos she wanted to work on her PhD thesis and me being gone for 6 months is actually helping...lol
data.author: Albert Lee

data.text: My wife is awesome.
data.author: Andy Harrington

data.text: I do 2 weeks to 3 weeks. At the starting point I encougre my partner to fly with me if possible. But always she will meet me at the end destination and we explore the city for a few days. Every day I will try to video call her. I pick up little gifts on the way. The best is communicating with your partner at all levels of the trip pre planning during and after. Walk them through your planning process your route. Make them feel comfortable with you being gone for awhile.
data.author: Jordan Dersch

data.text: that's all good advice. I like the gift idea.
data.author: Andy Harrington

data.text: A tough one, my girl has promised to do a tour with me but has backed out every time, she's okay with it though.
data.author: Paul Rodriguez

data.text: I think you know the answer‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ start riding
data.author: Kevin Hinton

data.text: Bike to work Go shopping Ride back Saturday Get up early ride 1 hour
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: I married one that likes to bike.
data.author: Chris Guevara

data.text: Personally i love trips but I don't like to be away from my wife more than a week or two at most. My brother however has taken many months long trips. His wife is more independent. However you must decide. It depends on your relationship and feeling of responsibility.
data.author: Rick Feightner

data.text: If they‚Äôre not supportive, they‚Äôre not the one for you. My husband has always been 100% on board on my long bike trips‚Ä¶he was supportive even when we first started dating.
data.author: Aspen Gentry

data.text: My husband doesn't want to bike tour and is busy farming in the spring and fall so I go without him.
data.author: Alison Emily Baker

data.text: We compromise. Every few weeks, you make stop in an interesting site for few days and he can join you for few days.
data.author: Mojca Visner

data.text: Date somebody that rides.
data.author: Joe Adams

data.text: This should be relatively easy for her, given men outnumber women who cycle more seriously by a large margin. Lots of choice for her
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.text: Have a great trip, and text and call to let them know you are having a great time (or maybe not so great sometimes, lol) and thinking of them. Hopefully they will see that this is a positive experience for you and be happy for you. If not, there are bigger problems.
data.author: Kristin Hamann

data.text: I got dumped, but... oh well!üòÇüö¥üèº‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è‚ù§Ô∏è
data.author: Judith Stoffer

data.text: I was very upfront with my partner when we started dating that biking for long periods was a high priority, and if that was a problem we couldn't overcome, that we weren't right for each other. We're now married, and I'm going away for 6 weeks this summer. It's about give and take, not "my way or the highway."
data.author: Drew Carlson

data.text: How would you feel if she was gone for 2 months? And now add the 'organized' part, means you have an awesome time with other people while she is alone. So consider the possibility that she's gone when you return.
data.author: Robert Polleros

data.text: It's fine. She doesn't want to go and likes her independent space. We've tried a couple of times but she just doesn't like it. So we do our own thing for however long the trip is. Various trips between 2 weeks to 5 months. We don't even communicate much. We each just go into solo mode. But we're long time married old. It probably is easier than if we were younger.
data.author: Daniel Ellsworth

data.text: I wrote & published bicycle tour guide books (circumnavigating 4 Great Lakes, the 11 NYS Finger Lakes, NYS Canal System & Hudson River Routes (now Empire state Trail). Many a relationship did not last while I was away for 2+ months (sometimes 4 or 5 months). Yes, I sent postcards & letters; telephoned (no cell phones & sketchy internet) most of the time I was traveling. Take the risk. Sometimes a relationship becomes stronger when there is distance between the individuals, sometimes not. Have no regrets that you pursued your quest for travel and new experiences.
data.author: Harvey Botzman

data.text: Priorities.
data.author: Casey Sha

data.text: You do you, boo. Your partner will figure it out, or not. Plenty of fish in the sea.
data.author: Jim Thill

data.text: M Scott Peck defines the essential nature of love as the will to extend one's self for the purpose.of nurturing one's own or another's growth. If it were 2 months on the beach in Cancun I could maybe do understand the objection but a 2 month bike touring trip offers a chance to challenge one's self and to grow. Maybe try explains this aspect to your partner and see if they can embrace the opportunity.
data.author: Trevor Piper

data.text: We do touring together
data.author: Sally Lloyd

data.text: If they care enough about you, they'll let you do what makes you happy.
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: Sadly, you must leave the partner and find a compatible bikepacker. No need to leave a note, just go.
data.author: Victor Veysey

data.text: , 50 ways to leave your lover..... ;-)
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: If you delve into why you might find the fears that this decision is based on. Fear of you growing apart? Fear of losing you to an accident? Fear of losing control of you? They can all be discussed, validated and work out how best to move forward.
data.author: Fi Charman

data.text: A strong relationship can survive 8 weeks. It's really not that long.
data.author: Tom Bielecki

data.text: Depending on other circumstances... I would also love to do a month or two, but i have 2 kids and a housing loan, so being away from family or work is impossible for me. I manage to arrange a week once a year, plus few more weekends, but other than that, no-go. But i already told my wife, when kids go to college and move away, I'm gone for a trip around the world üòÅ But in all fairness, it comes down to priorities in life, for both of you.
data.author: Ivan Perak

data.text: Is there a way where they can meet you periodically along the route in the evening when you're done riding for the day?
data.author: Patrick Mosiman

data.text: I've wondered why this isn't mentioned more often. Either spouse meets you at end of day, or at end of week, cyclist, if possible, takes bus, train, plane back home for the weekend.
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.text: It‚Äôs all about control and allowing oneself to be controlled. Not saying that‚Äôs bad but that‚Äôs what it boils down to.
data.author: Pete Gray

data.text: If you had to work for 2 months to make a pay check she might understand that philosophy. So explain how you only live once and the importance of it to your mental health and assure her she is always in your heart. Man I realize how lucky I am.. when I met the love of my life 9 years ago the first thing I did was encourage them to try biking. Lucky for me they also loved it even though before they thought they hated it with their terrible experiences riding with exs. Show her the way or buy her a trip for 2 weeks away that excites her. Ask her what would work and compromise is the key with you insisting you need to do this to breathe easily. üòäüëçüèºüòÄ
data.author: Jess Hills

data.text: I would arrange to,spend a couple of days together at an really nice place, every couple of weeks. Build these into your trip and also involved her in the planning and preparation.
data.author: Garry James

data.text: If they don‚Äôt want to let you live your life, are they worth spending it with? I‚Äôm assuming you aren‚Äôt leaving them with kids or pets you expect them to look after in your absence.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: I'm just getting into this and my wife isn't into biking. We will figure this out together when the long ride happens. She knows I have a passion for this that is building. I like the idea of her meeting up with me at various points or she can vacay with her sister along a route. There are other priorities in life to deal with too. It's a balancing act. Communicating is key. Include her as much as she's willing to be included. If you have a strong marriage, you will likely have little issues. If your marriage is already in trouble, then you better pick what's important do you and be okay with the outcome. You need your spouse as much as you desire adventure as you would hate to have had neither and wondered what you missed.
data.author: Erik Wresch

data.text: Relationships are about compromise. Okay so this year she isn't happy about a 2 month trip away. What about one month? Can she meet you anywhere en route for a couple of days? I don't ever go away for long stretches of time without my wife (and now newborn son), but I still manage a week once a year while she either goes to see family or friends while I'm away. Once our little guy is old enough, I'll be taking trips with him. And we'll do family trips as well.
data.author: Jayme Fraioli-Harper

data.text: Well, a partnership is about supporting each other not blocking. Would never want to stand in my partners way, as this only causes regret and probably even bitterness/frustration in the long run, which won't make the relationship any better. Your partner does not have to like it, but will have to accept it. As some people said, you only live once and you never know what could happen in the future (like an accident which will disable you from cycling). Go for it. Even more so if you are independent, using your own finances and no kids are involved.
data.author: Isa W√ºrth

data.text: It depends...... why is your partner not keen on you being away for that short length of time? Knowing that, will give you the starting point for altering the situation. :-)
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: short ...2 months.....
data.author: Nick Hanson

data.text: , nope! That's the length of time, but not the reason. üôÇ "Two months" being what? Your partner is worried you will forget him/her? Is dependent on your company to not be lonely? Is worried about paying all the bills whilst you are away? Is scared of being in the house alone? Anxious that you will decide to not come back? That you will meet someone else? That they will be left with all the chores for two months? Resents you going away having perceived fun alone/with others? Is a control freak? Needs someone else to be in control? Feels constant togetherness is the way to show commitment to a relationship? Or something else, could be entirely different? Best wishes for working it out.
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: Oops. Sorry Nick - I got your reply mixed up with the OP. I won't delete it, as it may be useful for others. (or not üòú ) Yes, I had wondered about whether to insert that "short" or not. Well, it's longer than just a day ride ( which some partners would object to. "What ? You want to be gone Aaaaallll day??" ) But it's not like going for a bike ride around the world for a year or five. üòÉ
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: you clearly are made to be single.
data.author: Nick Hanson

data.text: , where were you when I needed to be told that, fifty years ago???? üòõ
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: You are spot on! Until you know the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù, you can‚Äôt figure out a solution!
data.author: Nicole Dewey

data.text: Having served in my countries military for over 2 decades, my being gone for long periods just became part of our relationship and that‚Äôs carried over to retirement and cycling trips. Your partner must have their own interests that they take up when you‚Äôre gone. Anything besides pondering if you‚Äôre OK and when will you be home. It takes a strong relationship and a special king of partner to endear prolonged absences. Some relationships will survive it and improve. Many will not.
data.author: Greg Cook

data.text: When is the bike ride? I would like to join. I have these same concerns. But we need to live our life!!
data.author: Kimberly Carbone

data.text: Lots of communication, and focus on the relationship when you are there. It‚Äôs just like being away from work ..I‚Äôm on week 2/3 away currently myself. You will definitely appreciate them more when your home, if not it‚Äôs a sign
data.author: Steve Page

data.text: Fly and meet - they get a holiday and you get a life you want - win win
data.author: Bernard Smith

data.text: Just keep in contact sharing triumphs and disappointments so they feel involved, meet up along the way if possible...
data.author: Keith Yankeedoodle Kilcommons

data.text: works less well with a newborn!
data.author: Keith Yankeedoodle Kilcommons

data.text: this is exactly what I did and it worked out perfectly. No kids is the key!
data.author: Tom Hughes

data.text: Yeah, my pesky son really put a damper on adventures... He sure needs to grow up a bit faster so I can stick him somewhere in the adventure kit and get on the road again!
data.author: Keith Yankeedoodle Kilcommons

data.text: Maybe your partner rides an E-Bike?
data.author: Robert Reimann

data.text: Tandem
data.author: A. Jeffrey Tomassetti

data.text: Best person to ask is your partner. Only they know your relationship. Me saying I can do whatever an whenever isn't really going to help or make much difference
data.author: David Kitson

data.text: it‚Äôs a Facebook thing - looking for affirmation üëç
data.author: Bernard Smith

data.text: New partner or no partner.
data.author: Matt Haigh

data.text: I would talk it out and find a compromise tbh. I would miss my husband a lot if he was gone two months (we also have small children) but I could see the benefit to him on going on a shorter trip doing something he loved. Find out what are the easy things. Maybe he or she will say hey if you're gone for three weeks that's no problem, any longer and I feel x y z.
data.author: Maebh Murphy

data.text: Maybe try to do a bit less ? Like a month? Or do a a week break and try to encourage to take a week off to join somewhere in the middle of the 2 month?
data.author: Nathan Darellis

data.text: Relationships are built on trust. The day I left for my 2.5 month tour 6 years ago, I asked my now wife to be my girlfriend. As I got further away, we got closer by discussing the events and our thoughts on the experience.
data.author: Tom Hughes

data.text: My SO is doing their own vacation (stuff I'm not interested in) while I'm on my next bike tour.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: For me; we almost always travel together but we're keen on each other having their own things going on. For us, that's the healthy balance. Two months is a big-ish chunk of time, but I guess the bigger question os why don't they want you gone that long? IS it that they will miss you (sweet) or something else (not so sweet)? While them tagging along is not an option- could it be an option for them to drop in halfway through for a weekend? COuld they meet you at the end? Etc? Anytime my partner has been away has been rough (mainly just lonely) but I support him doing fun things and when he gets back I'm sure to decorate the house for a big homecoming and can't wait to hear the tales of the road. Edited to add: for safety I have their itinerary and they check in regularly so I don't worry.
data.author: Lindsey Hamma

data.text: Plenty of Diamonds!
data.author: Doug Ford

data.text: Get to the crux of why they aren‚Äôt supportive. Then find out what would ‚Äúneed to be true‚Äù for you to be able to go with their full support. Partners don‚Äôt always disclose their true reservations about these things. Maybe it‚Äôs a question of timing and home logistics (solvable). Maybe they are afraid for your safety (measures can be taken). Maybe they are jealous or insecure or worried about feeling lonely (much harder to address).
data.author: Claire Thompson

data.text: I am in relationship with my bicycle...which is also my faithful partner. Never nags,never asks where was I, why I am looking other bikes.... Who can not understand,support,tolerate this can go ....on his bike !
data.author: Ivo Kovacevic

data.text: keep her well lubed and pumped up lol.
data.author: Patrick Mosiman

data.text: Squeaky is good. Knocked up not so.
data.author: Ivo Kovacevic

data.text: Schedule hotel meet ups during the tour ?
data.author: Robert Draycott

data.text: I feel your pain.
data.author: Natalie Merrick

data.text: UPDATE: Thank you all so much for the responses!! I had another conversation with my partner about all of this and understanding it is something I really want to do, he was more supportive. This conversation had been hitting a wall for us the past couple of months -- this time I said I am going period, rather than asking what he thought about me going. Led to a good conversation and he is now supportive of my bike trip. Really appreciate everyone who commented.
data.author: Tabatha Dalponte

data.text: happy to hear and happy to help!
data.author: Liam Terry
